Quantum mechanics is a mathematical theory that has been very successful in describing a large number of phenomena. However, it is not a theory that is easy to understand. This is partly because it is a theory with a rich structure, and partly because it is a theory with a rich language. In this paper, we provide a mathematical foundation for quantum theory that is purely categorical. This means that the axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This has the potential to make quantum theory more accessible to a wider audience.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that have been hypothesized to have evolved from free-living cnidarians. To investigate the evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic one, we compared the genomes of two distantly related species, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that the myxozoan genome is one of the smallest reported in animals and that the parasite has lost many genes involved in development and cell–cell communication. These findings suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by a reduction in genome size and gene content. This evolutionary transition may have been facilitated by the loss of redundant functions in the parasite’s small genome. (Show more)

Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, including maize. Earlier studies suggest that once the optimum growing temperature is exceeded, mean crop yields decline and the variability of yield increases even if interannual climate variability remains unchanged. Here, we use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that as the global mean temperature increases, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation (CV) of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation (SD) of yields and a decrease in mean yields. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of species-level diet identification. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant African LMH species. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption inferred from mean sequence relative read abundance ranged from >99% (plains zebra) to <1% (dik-dik). Grass RRA was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of % grass consumption, indicating that RRA conveys reliable quantitative information about consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of size-matched grazers—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We survey more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, many businesses plan to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris in the ocean is a major concern for the marine environment. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected. This is mainly due to the size-selective sinks of plastic debris in the ocean interior. Our results suggest that the fate of the missing plastic debris is not only of fundamental importance to understand the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean, but also to understand the global carbon cycle. The origin of silicon carbide (SiC) grains is one of the most intriguing questions in presolar grain research. The formation of SiC grains in the interiors of AGB stars is a promising scenario. However, the origin of the interstellar exposure ages of SiC grains is still unknown. We determined the ages of 40 large SiC grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. Our ages range from 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. The grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We conclude that the grains condensed in outflows of AGB stars ∼7 Ga ago. Furthermore, we estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. Our results provide evidence for a long-term interstellar transport of SiC grains. This is important for the understanding of the formation of SiC grains in the interiors of AGB stars. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder of unknown etiology. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. Here we report the results of a proof of concept study in a mouse model of MSA, in which we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to mitigate α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in PLP-SYN mice. VX-765 was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy. Our results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the search for treatments for MSA. This study also provides a proof of principle for the use of VX-765 in a mouse model of MSA. The COVID-19 pandemic has been a major public health crisis. In response, many public health agencies and researchers have needed to track the pandemic and its impact on the population. However, the data available for tracking the pandemic have been limited. We have developed a suite of data sources and indicators that can be used to track the pandemic, and we have made this data available through an API. This paper describes the data sources and indicators, and provides examples demonstrating that the data can be used to track the pandemic, augment traditional public health reporting, and empower research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the target of many drugs. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is the site of ion conduction. The selectivity filter is also the site of all of the channel’s gating mechanisms. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. This allosteric communication is essential for the proper functioning of potassium channels. We have also demonstrated that the selectivity filter can be structurally collapsed by the structural collapse of the channel’s activation gate. This structural collapse is a key step in the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. The gut microbiome of herbivores is a dynamic community that is constantly changing in response to the host’s diet and environment. The role of the gut microbiome in the health of herbivores is not fully understood, but it is clear that the composition of the microbiome is important for the health of the host. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We find that anaerobic fungi synthesize a diverse array of natural products, including antibiotics, antimicrobial peptides, and other bioactive compounds. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are important producers of natural products that could be harnessed for the development of new therapeutics. Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. However, the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate during a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by the brain region the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and that this is a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is of great importance for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to discover optimal composite structures that seamlessly collaborate to produce arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The structures are digitally synthesized with multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct behaviors and seamlessly transition between different materials. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and heteroassembly. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general approach to design structures with desired behaviors and is expected to inspire the development of new materials and structures for mechanical applications.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of erythrocytes. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythrocytes is developmentally regulated and is influenced by a number of factors. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid cells. IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is silenced in the adult bone marrow. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 silencing in erythroid cells results in a reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This suggests that IGF2BP1 may be a key regulator of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Here, we show that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our findings indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP had little effect on the conservation of older-forest–associated birds. However, the policy did halt clearcutting on federal land, which has been critical to the conservation of older forests. We also show that the NWFP failed to halt the decline of early-seral–associated birds. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our findings also highlight the importance of monitoring and adaptive management in policy evaluation. This approach can help to ensure that policies are effective and that they are not inadvertently undermining the conservation of biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a challenging task, since the evolution of pathogens is fast and efficient. Therefore, computational approaches are essential tools to this end. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best candidate designed by us shows activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This approach can be used to develop new antibiotics against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). Over the Quaternary, we observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. These results have implications for the design of electronic devices and the timing of their use before bedtime. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. CTLA-4 is a key regulator of immune responses, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. We found that CTLA-4 is dispensable for the development of autoimmunity in the thymus, but is essential for the development of autoimmunity in the periphery. We also show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of Treg cell-mediated suppression. These findings provide a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification. Our analyses resolved previously controversial beetle relationships and revealed that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles. Moreover, corresponding (Jurassic) diversification rate increases suggest that these novel genes triggered adaptive radiations that resulted in nearly half of all living beetle species. We propose that beetle diversity resulted from multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding plant cell wall-degrading enzymes. This study thus provides a new perspective on the evolution of beetles and their symbionts. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also be relevant to other viruses that have emerged in recent years, such as Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus and severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2. Our approach may also be applicable to other protein molecules. Our results provide a proof-of-concept demonstration of the potential of deep learning in antibody engineering and its potential application to the development of next-generation antibody drugs.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. They also suggest that the relationship between population size and CCE may be nonlinear. This is an important finding, as it suggests that the relationship between population size and CCE may be different in different contexts. Our results have implications for the design of experiments and for the interpretation of results in the field of cultural evolution. They also have implications for the design of societies and for the evolution of technology. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the apoE allele, APOE4. APOE is a major protein of the brain and is highly expressed in astrocytes, a major cell type of the brain. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE alleles affect the accumulation of a protein that is a component of the classical complement pathway in senescent synapses. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a mechanistic link between APOE and AD pathogenesis. They also suggest a potential therapeutic target for AD treatment. This study also provides a rationale for the use of APOE as a biomarker for AD risk. This study also provides a rationale for the use of APOE as a biomarker for AD risk.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core with a diameter of about 2,300 km. It is the densest part of the Earth and is thought to be the remnant of the core formation process. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. In this study, we show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be two-step, which is different from the conventional one-step nucleation scenario. This two-step nucleation mechanism provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. Our study also provides a new perspective on the origin of the core anisotropy. This study is expected to contribute to the understanding of the inner core and the core formation process. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the drug is widely available, there is a need to understand the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). Specifically, marijuana abusers had significantly blunted responses to methylphenidate, including reduced decreases in striatal dopamine and reductions in the brain’s reward system. These findings suggest that chronic marijuana use is associated with decreased brain reactivity to methylphenidate, which might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers. Language is a uniquely human skill, and the brain’s processing of language is a central focus of neuroscience. However, the brain’s mechanisms for language comprehension remain poorly understood. Here, we use a state-of-the-art computational model to link brain and behavior in 200 experiments from 10 studies. We find that the model’s neural and behavioral fits are strongly correlated, and that model architecture contributes to both. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the brain’s language comprehension mechanisms. They also suggest that the model’s predictive representations could be measured in the brain. This approach could be extended to other cognitive and neural processes. It could also be used to study the neural basis of other complex human skills, such as music and math.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific computing problems. However, it is not clear whether this success is due to the power of DL or to the fact that DL is a black box. We show that the success of DL is due to the black box nature of DL. We prove that there are well-conditioned problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) with great approximation qualities. However, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This implies a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs with a given accuracy can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the success of deep learning in scientific computing. They also provide a theoretical explanation for the failure of deep learning in other areas of scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough. One of the most prominent arguments is that people’s inability to understand exponential growth is a key factor. This argument is based on a classic experiment published 45 years ago. Despite its flaws, the study is still cited as a classic. Here, we discuss the flaws of the experiment and how they undermine its conclusion. We also discuss the implications of this unique case study for the field of psychology and beyond.

Leprosy is a chronic disease that affects the skin, peripheral nerves, and central nervous system. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has undergone extensive reductive evolution, and is the subject of intense study. In contrast, the pathogenicity of the human pathogen, Mycobacterium lepromatosis, is unknown. Here we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which is similar to that of M. leprae. We also show that M. lepromatosis is more closely related to the ancient common ancestor of Mycobacterium and other pathogenic bacteria than is M. leprae. These findings suggest that M. lepromatosis is a potential pathogen and that the two leprosy bacilli have retained similar pathogenic potential since their ancient separation. Entanglement and entropy are central concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also fundamental to thermodynamics, the cornerstone of statistical mechanics. However, the relation between them is not fully understood. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics in isolated quantum systems can be completely described in the scaling limit of the time. This is a remarkable achievement, as it is not possible to compute the entanglement dynamics exactly in general. Our result is based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle descriptions of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our work paves the way for a deeper understanding of the relation between entanglement and thermodynamics in general systems. It also provides a powerful tool for the study of the dynamics of entanglement in many-body systems.

COVID-19, caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), has resulted in millions of deaths worldwide. Currently, there are no licensed vaccines against SARS-CoV-2. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, COVI-VAC, that is being developed by recoding the viral spike protein with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs (codon-pair deoptimization). This vaccine strain is temperature sensitive in vitro and robustly grows at the permissive temperature. In addition, the furin cleavage site within the spike protein was deleted from the viral genome for added safety of the vaccine strain. The vaccine was shown to be protective in hamsters, and the vaccine strain was shown to be highly attenuated. These results support the potential of COVI-VAC for use in mass vaccination programs. Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. It has been the subject of many historical studies, but the history of plague transmission is poorly understood. Here, we use a mathematical model to show that human ectoparasites were the primary vector for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1347–1353). Our results challenge the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in comparative neurobiology. However, it is not the only way to measure brain complexity. The number of neurons is the brain’s basic computational unit. We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only way to understand the evolution of brain complexity. We also show that the evolution of brain complexity is not only about brain size but also about the number of neurons. We also show that the evolution of brain complexity is not only about brain size but also about the number of neurons.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic structures that can be assembled and disassembled. The disassembly process is essential for many cellular processes, including cell motility. The disassembly process is also important for the repair of actin filaments that have been damaged by various mechanisms. In this study, we investigate the disassembly process of actin filaments in a physiological context. We find that the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins is a key regulator of the disassembly process. We show that ADF/cofilin can sever actin filaments in a mechanical context that is relevant to cells. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings provide insights into the disassembly process of actin filaments in cells. They also provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of ADF/cofilin in the repair of damaged actin filaments. This study is expected to be useful for understanding the disassembly process of actin filaments in cells. It may also lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for repairing damaged actin filaments in cells. Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a popular choice for dieters. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior have not been well characterized. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. Our results also suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of fructose on brain and behavior and for developing strategies to reduce the consumption of fructose. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample genomic diversity across Madagascar, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners to the Malagasy population. The admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It also provides a tool to study the history of other islands in the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Emotional contagion is the phenomenon of people experiencing the same emotions as others without their awareness. This work shows that people do not need to be in close proximity to each other to be influenced by the emotions of others. This work also suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media platforms. Messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences can be modified after transcription, and these modifications can have profound effects on gene expression. In this study, we show that the presence of a common modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in mRNA can modestly alter the rate of protein synthesis. We find that the presence of Ψ can promote the low-level synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the reconstituted translation system as well as human cells. Our work suggests that one consequence of the ribosome encountering Ψ can be to modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings highlight the potential for mRNA modifications to influence the rate of protein synthesis and may have implications for gene expression regulation. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social engagement, and time use. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounds, and the feeling that one’s life is worthwhile predicts positive changes in life satisfaction over a 4-y period. The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of aquatic mammals has been a major evolutionary story of the past 200 million years. However, the extent to which the aquatic lifestyle has driven the evolution of larger body sizes in these mammals has not been quantitatively tested. We show that the evolution of aquatic mammals is driven toward a size attractor in the range of 500 kg. This attractor is consistent with energetic constraints on the evolution of body size in the aquatic realm. This work provides a quantitative test of the hypothesis that the aquatic lifestyle has driven the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals. It also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of body size in other aquatic organisms. (Show more)

The common cold is the most common viral disease in the world. The virus responsible for the vast majority of colds is rhinovirus, which replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at body temperature. This study demonstrates that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is, at least in part, due to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. This study also provides a mechanism for the evolution of temperature-dependent growth in viruses adapted to the nasal cavity. These findings may also have implications for the development of vaccines and antiviral therapies for the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

Bacteria are constantly exposed to a wide range of environmental signals. In this study, we show that the type IV pili of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are used as a sensor to detect the presence of surfaces. This leads to a positive feedback loop that promotes long-term attachment to surfaces, which in turn can stimulate additional virulence and biofilm-inducing pathways. This mechanochemical model for surface sensing is unique to Pseudomonas aeruginosa and may be a general mechanism for sensing surfaces in bacteria. This finding has implications for understanding the role of pili in bacterial surface sensing and for developing new strategies to combat bacterial infections. This article is protected by copyright. The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study is a first step toward a better understanding of the global pesticide situation and its impact on the environment.

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has spread globally and is responsible for millions of deaths. The virus has been documented in many animal species, but the extent of the spillover events and the role of animals in the ongoing pandemic are unknown. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living deer. We also show that the virus has spread between deer and humans. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The world is moving toward a low-carbon energy future. The hydropower industry is moving to build large dams in the developing world. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to sustained microglial activation in response to Aβ plaques and cell death. Here, we show that neurons are also capable of producing potent immune factors, and that the extent of neuron-derived cytokines correlates with the extent of microglial activation and mobilization. We also demonstrate that neurons are vulnerable to Aβ accumulation in the human brain, and that the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a primary proinflammatory agent in AD. These findings suggest that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ may be a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. This may have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies to combat the disease. © 2015 American Association for the Advancement of Science.

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation remains elusive. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which demonstrates that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant during the fourth–second centuries B.C.E. We further show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study thus contributes to a better understanding of the process of the domestication and acclimatization of chickens. (Show more)

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress and have been shown to function as precursors to RNA caps. In bacteria, the predominant decapping enzyme, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that, in Escherichia coli cells experiencing such stress, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the main mechanism of immune dysfunction is the expansion of immunosuppressive cells. In this study, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is a key factor in the immune dysfunction observed in sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a metabolite of arginine, can restore the immune system and improve the clinical outcome of sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a new strategy for the treatment of sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the Earth system. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass is ≈2 orders of magnitude higher than previously estimated, and we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are key for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time and space, and the system’s dynamics become stationary and self-sustained at a certain time scale. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of the temporal activity. The most famous example is the sandpile model, which is a discrete model of SOC. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is widely used in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. However, its electronic properties can be further improved by tuning its bandgap. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and its bandgap can be fully closed. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, and its bandgap can be opened, by applying tensile strain. Our findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This article is protected by copyright. The role of plant-associated microbes in the health of the host plant is well established. However, the role of plant-associated microbes in the health of the pathogen is less understood. In this study, we show that a plant-derived peptide can kill plant fungal pathogens. The peptide is highly diverse and exhibits antimicrobial activity in vitro and in vivo. It binds to multiple phosphoinositides and induces reactive oxygen species in fungal cells. The peptide also binds to the fungal cell wall and penetrates the cell membrane at discrete foci. The peptide accumulates in the cytoplasm and the nucleoli of germlings. The peptide is effective against multiple plant fungal pathogens and can be used as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This study provides a proof-of-concept that plant-derived peptides can be used as a spray-on fungicide against plant fungal pathogens. This approach may be useful in the development of new and effective fungicides. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of intersexual continuity. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we show that the Drosophila sperm proteome undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. Multiple seminal fluid proteins initially associate with sperm, but most become undetectable after sperm are stored. Female-derived proteins also begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating, and they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Female-derived proteins that associate with sperm are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism, suggesting that female contributions support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is critical for hemostasis. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force can be used to switch the A1 domain of VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD. The force-switchable A1 domain is a general mechanism for activating protein interactions. This work provides a mechanism for understanding the effects of mutations in VWF and may be relevant to other proteins that bind to receptors on the surface of cells. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the subject of intense study for the past two decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that associate with humans, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, which will enable future studies of the virome and its impact on human health. The database is publicly available at https://www.humanviromes.org/.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate ACI. The HSRL can simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of the HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. We expect that this instrument will be a valuable tool for the community to understand ACI. Potassium channels are important for the normal function of the heart, brain, and kidneys. They are also involved in many diseases, including heart failure, stroke, and epilepsy. Potassium channels are also involved in the transmission of nerve signals. Potassium channels are activated by changes in the membrane potential and in the concentration of intracellular calcium. Potassium channels normally close to prevent the flow of potassium ions across the membrane. However, in some circumstances, potassium channels remain open and allow the flow of potassium ions. This can be harmful to the body. We studied the mechanism of potassium channel inactivation and found that potassium channels can be inactivated by closing. This is a new mechanism of potassium channel inactivation. We also found that potassium channels can be inactivated by opening. This is a new mechanism of potassium channel activation. These findings may lead to new treatments for diseases involving potassium channel dysfunction. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with millions of deaths each year. The parasite exploits a number of host cell signaling pathways to facilitate invasion of the red blood cell (RBC). Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane, which we show is required for invasion. This finding suggests that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This is a major change in our current understanding of the malaria invasion process. It also suggests that the parasite is not simply exploiting a single host cell signaling pathway but is instead using a number of different mechanisms to facilitate invasion. This would have important implications for the development of antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, photonics, and quantum applications. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks under mechanical stress. Therefore, it is difficult to apply diamond in mechanical devices. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized under mechanical strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized under strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work provides a new way to control the properties of diamond. It also provides a new way to control the properties of other materials with a wide bandgap. This work is expected to stimulate further research on the properties of materials with a wide bandgap. It also provides a new way to control the properties of materials with a wide bandgap. Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease in humans and animals. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of dry air on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is based on a single word at a time. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence, but suddenly decreases whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is consistent with a bottom-up parser of the incoming language stream. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is the first evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists. It also provides a new perspective on the brain’s processing of language.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a key regulator of development. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness to the pathway. This differential regulation may be used to fine-tune the pathway in different tissues. This is an example of how redundant genes can be regulated to achieve tissue-specific functions.

Obesity is a major health concern, and the mechanisms that promote overeating are not well understood. Here we show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus (LH) induces vigorous eating in sated mice. This effect is blocked by dopamine receptor antagonists and lesions of dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA). We also show that LH stimulation-induced eating is dependent on a circuit involving LH GABA neurons and neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the midbrain. This circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety, suggesting that it may contribute to overeating and contribute to obesity. This work provides a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. It also provides a target for the development of new strategies for the treatment of obesity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth and productivity. However, the nitrogen cycle is not closed in terrestrial ecosystems, and nitrogen must be supplemented to crops to achieve high yields. Symbiotic nitrogen fixation is a natural process that provides nitrogen to plants without the need for external inputs. However, the symbiosis is not closed, and the nitrogenase enzyme that fixes atmospheric nitrogen is not expressed in the absence of the bacterium. Here, we demonstrate a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, in which the nitrogenase is only expressed when the plant and bacterium are in contact. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This approach could be used to develop sustainable nitrogen-fixing crops that do not require external nitrogen inputs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest and a critical carbon sink. Despite the importance of the Amazon, there is no consensus on how to protect it. Some argue that the best way to protect the Amazon is to leave it alone. Others argue that the best way to protect the Amazon is to invest in remote-sensed monitoring and early warning systems. We study a community-based monitoring program that combines remote-sensed alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the program’s small sample size. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to perceive the world around them. The auditory organs of animals are diverse in structure and function, but all are part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. The web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. Climate change and air pollution are two of the most important global challenges of our time. We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use. We find that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. The chemical influence of air pollution on aeolian dust contributes to the aerosol cooling. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.51 °C and all pollution particles 0.73 °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36 °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives,

COVID-19 is a pandemic with over 500,000 deaths per week. Vaccine development has been accelerated, and several vaccines are in use or in late-stage clinical trials. However, the global vaccine supply is insufficient to contain the pandemic. We report a recombinant protein-based vaccine candidate that can be produced at large scale using recombinant viruses. The protein sequence used in this vaccine candidate is engineered to improve its yield, affinity, and immunogenicity. This vaccine candidate can be produced using a variety of expression systems, including bacteria, yeast, and mammalian cells. We also report a virus-like particle (VLP) vaccine candidate that can be produced using a single expression system. These vaccines can be produced at large scale, which will be critical for global access. The engineered protein sequence can be used in other vaccine candidates, and the VLP can be used in combination with other vaccine candidates. These vaccines can be produced using existing technologies and infrastructure, which will be critical for global access. (Show more)

Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor of childhood. It is a heterogeneous disease with a wide range of clinical behavior and a poor prognosis. In the last years, mutations in the gene encoding the proto-oncogene tyrosine protein kinase ALK were identified as a cause of sporadic and familial neuroblastoma. Recently, we identified secreted small ALKAL proteins (FAM150, AUG) as potential ligands for human ALK and the related leukocyte tyrosine kinase (LTK). Here, we show that zebrafish ALK/LTK and ALKALs activate each other and that loss of ALKALs causes ectopic iridophore development in vivo. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuroblastoma. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is one of the most dramatic events in the history of life. We present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a more complete picture of the pathogen’s evolution during this critical period. Our results suggest that the pathogen did not diversify significantly during this time, and that it spread rapidly across Eurasia. This study also reveals the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) and support for Donald Trump. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management practices that can increase SOC storage in grasslands remain uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that increase soil microbial biomass and diversity, such as incorporating legumes and manure into annual cropping systems, can increase SOC storage in Mollisols. In contrast, perennial pastures managed with rotational grazing increased SOC and mineral-associated organic matter (MAOM-C) by 18 to 29% over 29 y of management. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester soil carbon and highlight the importance of including grasslands in climate-smart agricultural systems. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a global system to identify and prioritize viruses with the potential to spillover and spread in humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors for zoonotic spillover and used this to rank 887 novel viruses from wildlife. We validated the framework using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of spillover potential can be used to inform research and public health interventions. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be a useful tool for policy makers and health scientists.

Nectar is a reward that many plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators. In this study, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also show that this alkaloid is attractive to the vertebrate-pollinator, Phelsuma geckos. This work identifies a convergently evolved trait in two plant species that are pollinated by hummingbirds. The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 475 and 675 AD. DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template during DNA replication. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in biology. In this work, we demonstrate that RNA can replicate and convert RNA into functional molecules in the absence of proteins. This represents a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life.

Urban change is a central topic in urban studies. However, the physical dynamics of urban change are difficult to observe and measure. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the initial appearance of the neighborhood, the density of college-educated adults, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. This work also provides a new way to measure the physical appearance of neighborhoods and cities. We hope that this work will inspire further research on the physical dynamics of cities.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but its high toxicity to eukaryotic cells has led to the development of copper-binding compounds in fungi. These findings suggest that the presence of the xan cluster in fungi is not limited to the production of siderophores, and that the copper-binding properties of xan BGC products may be important for fungal interactions with competing microbes. This study reveals a previously unknown role for fungal natural products in copper homeostasis and the mediation of interactions with competing microbes. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is an important factor in the transmission of infectious agents to vertebrate hosts. However, the mechanisms by which microbes influence vector health and pathogen transmission are poorly understood. Here, we show that the tick antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp) is expressed in response to Anaplasma phagocytophilum infection and is required for the efficient transmission of Anaplasma to the vector. Birds are one of the most successful animal lineages, and the study of their evolution is crucial for understanding their diversity and ecology. The study of the origin of the short-tailed bird group is critical for understanding the evolution of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, and show that it represents the second earliest diverging group of the Pygostylia. The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of water vapor. In this paper, we show that water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. This is significant because the stratosphere is not well understood, and it is difficult to model accurately.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal is important for its survival, as it can affect its ability to blend in with its environment. In this study, we show that the color of some animals can change over time. We also show that the color of some animals can change multiple times over time.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Breast cancer cells can be classified into two major populations: noncancerous cells and cancer stem cells (CSCs). CSCs are responsible for initiating and propagating tumor growth. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which increases the percentage of breast cancer cells that are tumorigenic and stem-like. This effect is mediated by hypoxia-induced HIF-1α and HIF-2α, which activate ALKBH5 expression and increase ALKBH5 protein levels. ALKBH5 demethylates N6-methyladenosine (m6A) at the NANOG mRNA 3′-UTR, which increases NANOG mRNA levels and the percentage of cells that are CSCs. The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was almost tissue-thin. The source of this parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the source of parchment in other historical documents. (Show more)

The age of the extinction is a key parameter for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target of the immune response in infected individuals. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in two forms that are currently circulating in the population. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein is associated with a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent fusion with the host cell membrane. This may explain the higher infectivity of the virus.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. This result is a generalization of the classical result of Moulin and Zamir (1991) to the case of repeated games.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a reduction in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. Our findings highlight the need for urgent action to address structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. These inequalities must be addressed in order to reduce the burden of COVID-19 and to improve the health of the nation.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry and biology. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms can be modified under pressure, and that these properties can be used to predict and explain chemical phenomena under pressure. This work is of fundamental importance in chemistry and biology, and it has implications for the understanding of the chemical properties of matter under extreme conditions.

Fire is a key climate-driven disturbance in terrestrial ecosystems. However, the effects of climate change and human demography on fire activity are poorly understood. We quantify the effects of climate and human demography on fire activity and carbon emissions using a coupled global climate–fire–carbon cycle model. We find that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. Our results highlight the importance of fire in mitigating climate change and the risk of more extreme fires in the future. This study emphasizes the need for a better understanding of the effects of climate and human demography on fire activity and carbon emissions. This is important for the design of effective climate mitigation strategies. (Show more)

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. We also show that this glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is required for the maintenance of a normal symbiont population level. Finally, we show that catabolism of this glycan by the symbiont modulates the pH of the symbiont’s habitat, which in turn enhances its capacity to produce bioluminescence at night. This study provides a mechanism by which animals may regulate the activities of their symbionts. It also suggests that the provision of nutrients to symbionts may be a more common phenomenon than previously thought. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous and increasingly important for understanding human behavior and social processes. However, text data are often unstructured and difficult to analyze. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and can be applied to a wide range of domains. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). Our method identifies 225 latent topics in the narratives, many of which are not captured by existing structured variables. Motivated by known patterns in suicide and homicide, we identify the gender bias of our topics and compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to a wide range of domains and can be extended to other types of data. It can also be used to identify latent patterns in text data.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common type of leukemia, and the prognosis of AML patients is poor. Here we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants.
