Crop experts are the backbone of the US agricultural system. They provide a wealth of information on crop status, but this information is not used to its full potential. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is the primary source of information on crop status, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. We also show that the CPC is not only a valuable source of information, but also a robust model that can be used to predict the future. This work demonstrates the potential of the CPC to provide early and more accurate predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. This can have a significant impact on the agricultural sector and the economy as a whole.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. This is a new approach to memory that does not rely on persistent activity, excitatory feedback, or synaptic plasticity. It is also sensitive to the context in which information is stored, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset of soil respiration measurements, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most fundamental events in the evolution of life on Earth. It is also one of the most challenging to model, as it is associated with a large number of changes in the environment and the lifestyle of the organisms. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, characterized by the dependence of the parasite on a host to fulfill its life cycle, rather than the loss of photosynthesis, is linked to the relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome. Our results have implications for the evolution of plastid genomes in general and for the evolution of parasitic lifestyles in particular. The chlorophyll pigments are the key intermediates in this process. (Bacterio)chlorophylls are the pigments of oxygenic photosynthesis, which is the only way of photosynthesis on Earth. Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal genes and the causal pathways. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to study the spreading of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. Our findings provide insight into the mechanisms of spreading and pathology in neurodegenerative diseases. They also suggest that the internalization of aggregates may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases. This study also provides a proof of principle for using Drosophila as a model to study spreading and neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system of bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit pathway, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and is a promising therapeutic target. Here we report the discovery of a series of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2. We show that these compounds are effective inhibitors of cancer cell growth in vitro and in vivo. We also show that formate, a one-carbon donor, can rescue cells from SHMT inhibition. However, formate is uniquely toxic to cells that are defective in glycine import, a process that is critical for SHMT enzymatic activity. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in a number of proteins, including superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), TDP-43, and Fused in Sarcoma (FUS). These proteins form intracellular inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, which are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. We observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for ALS. (PsycInfo Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The earliest flowering plants are poorly known, and the origin of the aquatic flowering plants is especially enigmatic. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, raises questions about the early evolution of the flowering plants.

Parvoviruses are small, nonenveloped DNA viruses that are ubiquitous in nature and are associated with a number of human diseases. The evolution of parvoviruses has been studied using genetic sequences from living species, but the evolution of the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is unknown. Here we present 10 ancient parvovirus B19 (B19V) sequences from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that ancient viral sequences can be used to study human evolution. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sea level is rising around the world. This rise is due to a combination of natural climate variability and human activities. The rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and the rate of acceleration is increasing. This acceleration is due to the same human activities that are causing global warming.

Pain is a major public health problem, but the course of pain over the life course is not well understood. We show that pain increases with age in the United States, but that this pattern is not seen for those with less education. Pain increases with age for all adults, but tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly.

The tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate is a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure and chemical dynamics of this intermediate. The results provide a detailed picture of the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state, including the location of the water molecule that acts as a hydrogen bond donor to the ε-amino group of the βLys87 catalytic residue. This analysis highlights the importance of the active site environment in determining the reaction pathway. The chemically detailed, three-dimensional structure from NMR-assisted crystallography is key to understanding why indole, an isostere of the natural substrate, reacts, while benzimidazole, does not. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography for mechanistic enzymology. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe and often fatal disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the available treatment options are limited. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum inhibitor of viral replication that has shown efficacy in vitro against MERS-CoV. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic remdesivir treatment in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection prevented disease and reduced virus replication and lung lesions. These data support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of benefit to patients and the wider community. The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts only at night, when the squid is producing light. We propose that this strategy may be used by other hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades. This study shows that a scalable, online intervention can reduce suspension rates by half. It also shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships is a key driver of suspension rates. Finally, it shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed. These findings have implications for policy and practice.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. We also identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings will help to understand the molecular mechanisms of transcriptional mutagenesis and provide important information for the development of DNA alkylation-resistant drugs. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. The food system is a major contributor to global environmental change and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food system also has a major impact on population health. In this work, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria by 50% increased the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 40% in a large-scale field study. This increase was sustained over time, and it was concentrated among diners who had previously purchased fewer vegetarian meals. These results provide robust evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. Our findings suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering settings could have a significant impact on population health and the environment. This approach could be easily implemented and would be a low-cost, high-impact way to contribute to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for engaging the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a collection of isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a significant contribution to the field of cancer biology and drug discovery. It is also a model for how quantitative proteomics can be applied to the study of the cell surface. The

In response to coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that 1) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, 2) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and 3) universal vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented without compromising the integrity of the electoral process.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global population. The virus has spread rapidly, and the molecular basis for its spread and severity is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not seen in SARS-CoV. This dimerization interface is unique to SARS-CoV-2, and we show that it is essential for the virus to spread and cause disease. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the spread of SARS-CoV-2 and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats and that this is mediated by the hypoxic-induced release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. We further show that CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 may be a potential target for the treatment of cerebral edema in hypoxia. This study may also provide a theoretical basis for the development of new drugs for the treatment of cerebral edema in hypoxia. (PsycINFO Database Record

The world is full of associations. We are surrounded by them. We make them every day. We use them to make decisions. We use them to understand the world. But, as we have learned, associations are not necessarily causal. They may be the result of chance. So, how do we assess the strength of associations? This paper describes a new approach to selective inference. It is a way of setting a higher bar for declaring significant associations. It is a way of being more cautious. It is a way of being more responsible. It is a way of being more scientific.

Endothelial cells (ECs) are the most important cells in the formation of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs has become increasingly important for providing vascular plexus to regenerated organs, such as the liver. Although many attempts have been made to generate ECs from pluripotent stem cells and nonvascular cells, the minimum number of transcription factors that specialize in directly inducing vascular ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, transduced ETV2 elicits expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are a family of transmembrane receptors that are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. In addition to their role in development, RTKs are implicated in a variety of diseases, including cancer. In the last few years, two new ligands for RTKs have been discovered. These ligands, named augmentor, are expressed in the neural crest and are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized type of photoreceptor cells. Here, we show that augmentor ligands are essential for the development of iridophores in zebrafish. We also show that augmentor ligands are activated by Ltk and not by Alk. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that augmentor ligands and Ltk are involved in the development of iridophores in a tissue-specific context. This study provides a better understanding of the role of augmentor ligands in the development of iridophores and may lead to the discovery of new therapeutic targets for cancer and other diseases. Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cell remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency impaired β-cell function and insulin secretion, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. These findings revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings also provide a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of T2D. This study may also provide a new perspective for the study of STING in other diseases. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The viral genome is segmented into eight RNA fragments, which complicates the packaging process. The selective packaging of the viral genome is essential for the production of infectious virions. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides insights into the packaging mechanism of influenza A viruses. It also offers a potential target for the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that leads to the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in blood vessels. The focal nature of atherosclerotic lesions suggests an important role of local hemodynamic environment. Recent studies have demonstrated significant roles of Yes-associated protein (YAP) and transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in mediating mechanotransduction and vascular homeostasis. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen dramatically in recent decades. Climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. Urban change is a central topic in urban studies. However, the physical dynamics of urban change are difficult to observe and measure. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work also provides a proof of concept for a new approach to urban studies that combines computer vision and big data. We hope that this work will inspire others to use computer vision methods to study urban change.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved. This article is protected by copyright. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the within-host dynamics of ZIKV infection are likely important. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We find that the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also find that the within-host basic reproductive number R0 is likely higher than 1, suggesting that the virus can spread in the population. We assess the effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication and find that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced by ∼2 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. This treatment is thus likely to be effective in reducing the spread of the virus. These results provide a framework for the design of future clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a major stressor of coral reefs worldwide. The breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is accompanied by a loss of reef building capacity and a decline in ecosystem services. While the symptoms of bleaching have been extensively characterized, the underlying processes remain largely unknown. Here, we show that altered nutrient cycling during heat stress is a primary driver of the functional breakdown of the symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the host from the environment. In the case of cancer, the epithelium becomes leaky and allows the entry of pathogens and toxins. Here, we show that the intestinal tumor microenvironment can alter the composition of the microbiome and trigger a regenerative response. This leads to a loss of barrier function and a dysbiotic microbiome, which in turn promotes tumor growth. Our work identifies a mechanism by which the tumor microenvironment can alter the composition of the microbiome and highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the tumor microenvironment in the dysregulation of the microbiome and the intestinal barrier, and it may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. Chemotherapy is a major treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to this therapy. In this study, we show that the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is expressed in breast cancer cells and is up-regulated following chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and to form tumors in mice. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab enhances the response to chemotherapy. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is still a matter of debate. We show that the start of deglaciation is linked to a unique volcanic event, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and climate changes that are similar to those associated with modern ozone depletion over Antarctica.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people around the world. However, they are often overlooked in global assessments of biodiversity and ecosystem services. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that most catches come from rivers with high stress levels. Our analysis also shows that inland fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poorest people. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our data can be used to inform conservation and sustainable use of riverine biodiversity. This approach can help to protect the ecosystem services that freshwater fisheries provide to the world’s poorest people.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable character of the material is the key to achieve high energy density and long cycle life. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a key feature of the adult nervous system. However, the molecular mechanisms that control this capacity are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery is important because it suggests that regeneration is a more general property of the nervous system than previously thought. Moreover, it provides a platform for discovering new factors that control the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity.

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous DNA sequences during the process of DNA replication. It is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in populations and for the repair of DNA damage. In humans, recombination is the primary mechanism by which new genes are created. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is concentrated in hotspots, interspersed with cold regions. The hotspots are similar to those observed in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the pattern of recombination in flowering plants may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms. This study provides a detailed view of recombination in a flowering plant and may be of use in the study of recombination in other organisms. This article is protected by copyright. The resting brain is a complex system, with a large number of functionally interacting networks. The identification of these networks is a key step in understanding the organization of brain function. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant metabolic RSN was deactivated during task performance in healthy subjects and early PD patients. In contrast, in PD, the subordinate RSNs were activated during task performance. These results provide a direct measure of the resting organization of the brain in health and disease. They also provide a basis for further studies of the functional significance of these networks.

RNA modifications are important for gene expression in bacteria and are now being discovered in eukaryotes. In bacteria, 5′ RNA modifications are found on a subset of mRNAs and are thought to play a role in mRNA export. In this study, we show that 5′ NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. NAD-RNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because it is also found on pre-mRNAs. This 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This discovery expands the repertoire of RNA modifications in eukaryotes and raises the possibility that 5′ NAD-RNA could be involved in gene regulation. (Show more)

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. The mechanisms of metabolic memory are not fully understood. Here we show that epigenetic DNA-methylation patterns at specific loci in whole blood and monocytes of people with diabetes are altered during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and persist for several years during the long-term follow-up of the EDIC Study. These epigenetic alterations are associated with glycemia and support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. Our findings may also have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies to improve metabolic memory. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This study may also provide a potential therapeutic target for TNBC treatment. (PsycInfo Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high prevalence and a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

Tomato fruit are among the most popular fruits in the world, and the quality of their flavor is of great importance to consumers. The biosynthesis of the volatiles that contribute to the flavor of tomato fruit is not known. We report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce these compounds. This work provides a major advance in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor, and it is a major step forward in the development of improved tomato cultivars. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the conservation and management of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning in a warming world. This article is protected by copyright. The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub of the hippocampal circuit. It is thought to create a map of local space, based on the activity of grid, head-direction (HD), border, and object-vector (OV) cells. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is debated. Here, we used portable two-photon microscopes to record from a large number of neurons in MEC and parasubiculum during unrestrained behavior. We found that grid cells are anatomically distinct from border, HD, and OV cells. These data suggest that grid cells might be largely independent from other cell types. Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not required for flowering of the host plant in a host–parasite interaction. Instead, FTs are able to move from the host to the parasite, where they physically interact with a dodder FD transcription factor to activate dodder flowering. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of flowering in plants. It is likely that flowering is a trait that has been lost several times in different lineages of plants. Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing neurons of the substantia nigra. The disease is associated with a loss of dopamine-containing neurons and a reduction in dopamine release in the striatum. The cause of this loss is unknown, but it is thought to be due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors. The present study shows that the dopamine-producing neurons are connected to other brain regions, including the striatum, via a specialized system of neurons in the substantia nigra. These neurons are densely packed into clusters of cells that are connected to striatonigral fibers. These clusters of cells are reminiscent of the bouquet-like structures found in the brain of other animals. We suggest that these structures are critical to the function of dopamine-producing neurons in health and disease. This study provides insight into the structure of the dopamine system in the brain and its relationship to other brain regions. It also provides a potential target for the development of new treatments for Parkinson’s disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection. We also seek speed. But how do we know when two people are connected? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed of communication is a robust signal of connection. We found that people felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. This signal was used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes that are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN cells are able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. We report here that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN function. STIM1 is selectively expressed in SAN cells and is required for maintaining the integrity of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores. STIM1 regulates SAN function by modulating the activity of store-operated Ca2+ entry and the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These findings reveal a previously unknown mechanism by which STIM1 contributes to the electrical activity of the SAN. This study provides insight into the molecular basis of SAN function and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for heart failure. (Show more)

Ether lipids are a class of membrane lipids that are important for membrane stability and function. They are synthesized from glycerol and fatty acids and are cleaved by alkylglycerol monooxygenase to produce fatty acids that are used in the synthesis of other lipids. Tetrahydrobiopterin is a cofactor that is synthesized from GTP and is essential for alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important for ether lipid metabolism in murine macrophages. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important for the regulation of macrophage activation. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. This study provides a basis for further studies on ether lipid metabolism in macrophages and for the development of new therapeutic strategies for diseases associated with ether lipid metabolism. Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. The brain is thought to accomplish this through the maintenance of information in the firing rates of neurons. Here we propose a different mechanism for memory that relies on the adaptive changes in the conductances of neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Nutrient pollution is one of the most pervasive threats to aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient pollution comes from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, little is known about the relative importance of small tributaries in driving coastal nutrient inputs. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas, especially in large water bodies. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient pollution on valuable nearshore ecosystems. Our results have implications for understanding the role of small tributaries in driving coastal eutrophication in other large water bodies around the world.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to a small set of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is driven by a small set of external forces. We discuss the implications of our findings for the study of complex systems in general.

The Earth system is currently undergoing a rapid transition from a greenhouse to an icehouse climate. This transition is expected to be abrupt and potentially catastrophic for life on Earth. However, the history of abrupt climate change in the past is poorly understood. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred ∼304 Ma during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global warming and anoxia of the deep ocean. Our results provide insights into the potential for abrupt climate change in the future and the potential for life to survive such a change. This article is protected by copyright. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification is associated with reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for tropical deforestation, but it is an important tool in the toolbox of policies to reduce tropical deforestation. The exocyst complex is a protein complex involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is evolutionarily conserved, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a key process in the evolution of vertebrates. In many species, sex is determined by a single genetic locus. In others, sex is determined by multiple interacting loci, resulting in a spectrum of genotypes that can be phenotypically male, female, or intermediate. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles in a species with polygenic sex determination. We find that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Our results suggest that the maintenance of sex determination alleles is not a binary process, but rather a dynamic one that can be modulated by the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics. This provides a framework for understanding the evolutionary consequences of sex determination alleles in vertebrates. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Predator specialization is a key process in the evolution of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators, can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type have evolved into specialists on other prey types. Our findings suggest that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of tentilla and their nematocysts. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also help build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. Despite the discovery of relatively complete hands from two early hominin species (Ardipithecus ramidus and Australopithecus sediba) and partial hands from another (Australopithecus afarensis), fundamental questions remain about the evolution of the human hand. These questions are driven by the paucity of hand fossils in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old, a time interval well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of Acheulian technology. We show that the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand, was present ∼1.42 Mya in an East African hominin from Kaitio, West Turkana, Kenya. This fossil thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit pathway, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and is a promising therapeutic target. Here we report the discovery of a series of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2. We show that these compounds are effective inhibitors of cancer cell growth in vitro and in vivo. We also show that formate, a one-carbon donor, can rescue cells from SHMT inhibition. However, formate is uniquely toxic to cells that are defective in glycine import, a process that is critical for SHMT enzymatic activity. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. In this study, we show that deforestation can affect people’s diets and that this effect is likely to be negative. This finding has important implications for policy makers, who have largely overlooked forests in strategies to improve nutrition. Our results suggest that forests can be a source of food and nutrition security, and that they can contribute to meeting the global nutrition goals. This study also highlights the need for more research on the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets. This is particularly important in light of the current global food crisis.

Modern farm machinery has greatly increased agricultural productivity, but at the cost of higher vehicle weights that have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We show that subsoil compaction has become a global phenomenon, with potential loss of productivity. We hypothesize that the roaming of sauropods on land, which is now a highly compacted environment, may have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. Our findings call for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. This may be a critical factor in the success of modern mechanization and the future of agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.
